STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 14, 2019
Leo Giori Jr
Iosco/Alcona County DHHS
2145 E Huron Road
East Tawas, MI 48730
RE: License #: CP350201199
Iosco/Alcona County DHHS
2145 E Huron Road
East Tawas, MI 48730
Dear Mr. Giori Jr:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on July 18,
2019. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, area manager at 616.552.3662.
Sincerely,
Bill White, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-5037
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP350201199
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Iosco/Alcona County DHHS
Facility Address: 2145 E Huron Road
East Tawas, MI 48730
Facility Telephone #: (989) 362-0300
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1992
Service Types:
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 7/1 – 5, 2019

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, an
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors),
and provided to the foster care provider.
One of the homes visited by the field analyst reported not receiving a medical
passport. This was confirmed by a review of MiSACWIS. There were two passports
partially filled in, and neither had any signatures.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08 Supervisory Approval - USP
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required assessments
(FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and approved by the
foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face meeting with the
foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
4

• For DHS supervisors, select the approved button in the
SWSS-FAJ Supervisory Selection field to generate the SWSS-
FAJ transaction.
• Sign and date the original approved case service plan.
The DHS and placement agency foster care (PAFC) USP
approval date is identified by the foster care worker and
supervisor signatures and date on the last page of the USP. A
copy of the USP with the two signatures and dates must be
placed in the narrative section of the case record.
The agency is considered out of compliance with licensing rule
R400.12403(2)(o) if the foster care supervisor signature date is
past the 14-day review and approval time frame.
Two of ten Updated Service Plans were signed by the supervisor after the 14-day
requirement. One was signed 2 days late and one was signed 1 day late.
FOM 722-6H CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
PLACEMENT
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement Move
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with the child for the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face
contact with the child must take place within five business days
from the date the case is assigned to the caseworker or within
five business days of the date of the placement move. At least
one contact each month must take place at the child’s
placement location. Each contact must include a private
meeting between the child and the caseworker; see Private
Meeting in this item.
Note: A month is defined as 30 calendar days, unless otherwise
specified; for example, calendar month.
One of ten Updated Service Plans reviewed the Caseworker only had one contact in
the 2nd month of the child’s placement into foster care; 2/12/19.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas. None required
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas: None required
5

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period for the following:
●Renewal Inspection December 19, 2018
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
ISEP 6.33(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age
to participate.
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
FOM 722-6H Unannounced Home Visit CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH
CAREGIVERS
FOM 722-6H CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
PLACEMENT
FOM 722-03B DHS-3130A, RELATIVE PLACEMENT HOME STUDY
FOM 722-03B RELATIVE PLACEMENTS
Alcona/Iosco DHHS continues to comply with their CAP for the above violations.
VII. Analyst Report:
Critical Alert 1:
1. The foster parent does not have insurance cards for the children in the home.
2. The foster parent is not aware of an FTM being held for one child in the home.
Resolution:
1. Foster parent was given the DHS 3762 for medical authorization. Verified in
MiSACWIS
2. Foster parent participated in FTM on 06/18/2019 by phone. Foster parent has
been invited to previous FTM’s and Foster parent gives information prior to FTM
when they can’t make it. This was confirmed in MiSACWIS
Critical Alert 3:
1. The assigned worker has not made more than one visit during the first month of
placement.
2. The licensing process took longer than 6 months.
3. The foster parent was not given all of the medical information of the child at the
time that the agency was requesting placement.
4. The foster parent was not given the medical authorization card at the time of
placement.
6

5. The foster parent was not given information on resources available to help her
care for the child. For example, the foster parent was not told that her
transportation expenses could be paid by the insurance until after she had made
several trips from Tawas to Saginaw. The foster parent was not made aware of
community resources for clothing. The foster parent is still waiting for foster care
payments and clothing allowance for the child.
6. The foster parent needs the insurance card for the child.
7. The foster parent does not have the medical passport for the child in the home.
8. The foster parent is not aware of providing input into a treatment plan or signing a
treatment plan.
Response:
1. Youth moved on 3/22/2019; A month is defined as a 30-day period. Foster care
worker made visits in the foster home: 03/25/2019 and 03/28/2019. Second month
begins on 4/22/2019 and contacts occurred on: 05/03/2019 and 05/17/2019.
Verified in MiSACWIS
2. Foster Parent expressed an interest in becoming a licensed foster parent and
signed an application on 5/21/18 and enrolled in June of 2018. MiSACWIS help
desk request was done on 11/20/18. Report was approved on 1/16/19 and
submitted to DCWL. Verified in MiSACWIS
3. File was reviewed and the foster parent was informed of the medical needs at
time of placement.
4. Foster Parent was given medical authorization card on 03/22/2019 by CPS
worker. Verified in MiSACWIS
5. Foster parent was advised during PRIDE trainings of the local resources as well
as during placement of the youth of the availability for assistance with youth’s
medical needs, including transportation reimbursement. Verified in MiSACWIS
6. Foster Parent was given medical authorization card on 03/22/2019 by the CPS
worker. Verified in MiSACWIS
7. MiSACWIS was reviewed: Two medical passports were generated in the system,
but were not completed and had several blank boxes. There were not signatures
for either passport. This is a violation of ISEP and FOM 801 – Medical Passports.
It is cited as a violation above and requires a CAP.
8. Foster parent signed the initial parent agency treatment plan and was given a
copy of the plan. Verified in MiSACWIS
Critical Alert 4:
1. One birth parent is not involved in decisions about her children's medical and
educational decisions, or decisions about their personal appearance. Also not
notified of medical appointments.
2. One birth parent does not feel respected by her assigned case manager. The
case manager only has contact with her the day before court when she receives a
text reminder of court.
3. One birth parent has custody of one child and she would like to bring this child to
visits so they can see their half siblings. The worker will not allow this.
4. One birth parent has not had an in-home visit by the assigned case manager.
5. One birth parent does not have monthly contact with the assigned case manager.
7

6. The relative home has not had a quarterly unannounced home visit by the
assigned case worker.
Response:
1. 10/01/2019 petition filed to remove youth from Guardianship due to sexual abuse.
On 10/23/2019 petition filed to terminate parental rights of mother and reunification
with father of youth. Mother pled to termination petition. Verified in MiSACWIS
2. This is not a licensing rule violation. Mothers parental rights terminated. Verified in
MiSACWIS
3. Child has no biological connection to the kids in care, as this child is the live-in
partners child. Verified in MiSACWIS
4/5. Mother pled to termination petition. Worker contact not is required. Verified in
MiSACWIS
6. Unannounced visits to the relative home were verified as documented in
MiSACWIS each quarter since initial placement in October 2018.
Critical Alert 6:
1. Medical authorization card not given at the time of placement.
2. The relative does not have a medical passport for the child in the home.
3. The relative caretakers are not aware of signing a treatment plan.
4. The relative caretakers do not feel supported by the agency because of the lack of
explanation of licensing rules. For example, they were not able to keep their guns.
They had several chickens at the beginning of the case but since they cannot have
firearms their chickens are being killed by animals.
5. The relative states the room at DHHS where parenting time takes place is dirty
and the toys are also not clean.
6. One birth parent participated in the FTM by phone. He would have liked to
participate in person. Transportation is a barrier for him.
7. One birth parent would like more contact with the assigned case manager. He has
only seen the worker at court and one time at the child's placement. There has not
been one on one case management with the assigned case manager.
8.One birth parent does not have a scheduled weekly visit with his child.
Response:
1. Medical Auth card DHS 3762 given at placement on 02/07/2019 @ 4:40pm by
CPS removing worker. Verified in MiSACWIS.
2. Medical passport information was obtained from parents and medical passport
given to relatives on 03/08/2019 and obtained signatures. Verified in MiSACWIS.
3. ISP was generated and the parents have signed. Foster care worker did not
obtain relative signatures as required. Foster care worker has discussed with
supervisor and a change in procedures of signatures was implemented within the
foster care department to ensure all signatures obtained timely on reports.
Consultant note: Agency discovered error and was corrected along with procedure
change prior to review – CAP accepted.
4. Agency did not state guns had to be removed. Rules provided regarding guns and
signed by foster parent. Verified in MiSACWIS
8

5. Supervised visitation took place in MDHHS visit room on 04/09/2019. Rooms are
picked up after visits and toys cleaned. Verified by policy/procedure.
6. FTM: CPS contacted parent on 02/08/2019 @ 2:43pm by telephone for pre FTM
conversation and set up FTM. Parent determined they would participate by phone.
Contact narrative viewed. MDDHS presented BOTH parents with gas cards in the
amount of $40 each to assist with transportation for their services on 02/26/20.
Verified in MiSACWIS
7. Father resided in Otsego County at the time of removal. Courtesy worker was
requested for father on 03/05/2019, Father has not been cooperative with allowing
worker at the home and has only met with them at the Otsego DHHS office.
Consultant verified numerous contact attempts by worker in MiSACWIS.
8. Father completed visitations on the following dates 03/02/2019 and 03/15/2019.
Father missed the following visitations due to transportation concerns 03/07/2019
and the father and mother missed the following visitations without communication or
explanation on 03/14/2019, 04/10/2019, 04/16/2019, 04/17/2019, 04/23/2019,
04/24/2019, 04/30/2019, 05/01/2019, 05/07/2019, 05/08/2019, 05/14/2019,
5/15/2019. 05/21/2019, 05/22/2019, 05/28/2019 and 05/29/2019. Parents have been
engaging in regular visitation with their son since 06/04/2019. Verified in MiSACWIS
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
August 7, 2019
________________________________________
Bill White Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 14, 2019
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
9
